One method is called the broken record technique: &quot;No matter what the salesperson says, you just keep repeating, &#39;I want to pay no more than $X for this car.&#39;&nbsp; By repeating yourself like a broken record, you wear the salesperson down&quot; (Wilfred, 2004, p. 12).&nbsp; Another method is the signed-sealed-delivered technique: &quot;When you use this technique, you tell the salesperson, &#39;I will sign the contract as soon as you agree to the price I think is fair for the car&#39;&quot; (Wilfred, 2004, p. 12).&nbsp; A third technique focuses on mutual respect and finding a price that is fair to both the buyer and the seller (Wilfred, 2004).&nbsp; After all, &quot;a car is a major investment, and you have to plan not only for the purchase price but also the cost of upkeep and maintenance&quot; (Browning, 2016, p. 40). &nbsp; </span></p></td></tr></tbody></table>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_806a9486-8112-0722-bdd8-0f3aaeffacb1\" style=\"width: 200px; </em>Using a signal phrase is considered citing.&nbsp; It lets the reader know the author of your source.<br />&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <img alt=\"For example, you start a paragraph with your own ideas.  At the end of your own ideas, you start the next sentence with the signal phrase As Tara Browning (2016) explains, and follow this with words and ideas of Tara Browning that support your points.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p><p>If your signal phrase introduces a <strong>direct quotation</strong>, also include the page or paragraph number after the direct quotation and before the period:<br />&nbsp;</p><p style=\"margin-left: 40px;\"><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">According to Tara Browning (2016), &quot;A car that looked great on the outside might have had terrible mechanical or electrical problems&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(p. 40)</span>.</span><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><br /><br />&nbsp;</p>","headerText":"Using signal phrases"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>Which signal phrase in this paragraph from your article indicates that ideas are borrowed from another source?</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\">Used-car buyers today can find some consolation in the fact that today&#39;s cars are much better mechanically than the cars of earlier generations.&nbsp; As Tara Browning (2016) notes in an article for <em>The Consumer Advocate</em>, &quot;A car that looked great on the outside might have had terrible mechanical or electrical problems&quot; (p. 40).&nbsp; In fact, cars of the 1970s and 1980s were often unreliable or even dangerous (Browning, 2016).&nbsp; Cars manufactured after 2000 are light-years ahead of earlier cars in terms of quality and reliability.</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_ab9cafe0-edc9-1d46-315c-828295ee2e87\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">MC Placeholder<br /><strong>ID: mc_ab9c...</strong></jumc><span>&nbsp; </span></p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>If you do not choose to use a signal phrase, you include a citation with the author&#39;s name at the end of the direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary:</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\">Used-car buyers today can find some consolation in the fact that today&#39;s cars are much better mechanically than the cars of earlier generations. &nbsp; &quot;A car that looked great on the outside might have had terrible mechanical or electrical problems&quot;<span class=\"marker\"> (Browning, 2016, p. 40).</span></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>Is it better to cite your source using the&nbsp;author&#39;s name in a signal phrase or with an in-text citation?&nbsp;<br /><br />The choice is yours.<br /><br />Good writers vary their style to keep readers&#39; interest.&nbsp; Try reading your work aloud and experimenting with both ways of acknowledging the author or source.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>If you use many pieces of information from the same source within one paragraph, acknowledge the source <strong>each time</strong> you include a direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary in the paragraph.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Citing the same source more than once in a paragraph"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>This paragraph from your article includes information that comes from an article by Dar Francise, published in 2015.</p><p>It includes two summaries and a direct quotation, all from Francise&#39;s article.&nbsp; Indicate whether each sentence requires a citation.</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p style=\"line-height:250%;\">Before buying a used car, you should learn as much as you can about its history, because &quot;not every car was driven gently by an experienced, cautious driver&quot; <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_35ead2c8-23dc-6b85-d2de-a2f373f41d39\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_35ea...</strong></jumc>.&nbsp; Armed with the vehicle identification number (VIN), you can access a large amount of free information about the car, including ownership records, maintenance records, and repair records <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_3fc88cf1-9561-43c1-dbb4-b1dde8cb6948\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_3fc8...</strong></jumc>.&nbsp; Some reports also tell you whether the car has ever been involved in a flood.&nbsp; You can choose to purchase a detailed vehicle history report (VHR) yourself, or you can ask the owner or dealership to provide it.&nbsp; Many car sellers are happy to so, because the report shows the buyer that the car is in good condition <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_2e41444e-0426-8e00-ae45-904babcdbe63\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong>ID: mc_2e41...</strong></jumc>.&nbsp; Before I purchased my pre-owned Ford Focus two years ago, I ordered a CARFAX report on a used Toyota Prius, and I learned that it had been in a flood <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_467f9ea7-4e25-1d09-3d65-070f7612f5d9\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_467f...</strong></jumc>.&nbsp; I steered clear of that car and purchased the Focus instead.&nbsp; The CARFAX report for the Focus showed that it was owned by only one person, had low mileage, and had never been involved in an accident <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_8ce80b97-cb88-3c1d-091e-189a30474141\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong>ID: mc_8ce8...</strong></jumc>.</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>You can use a signal phrase to acknowledge the source each time you use it.<br /><br />If you use a signal phrase more than once, then you only need to include the date in parentheses the first time you mention the source.</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>In this paragraph, you use two ideas by Gary Wilfred.&nbsp; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_c952...</strong></jumc> car salespeople are motivated to sell cars because their compensation depends upon the number of cars they sell. <jumc ju-mc=\"mc_6d07ad67-daed-94da-2091-f9ddd793d1b3\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_6d07...</strong></jumc> also mentions that many car salespeople have a &quot;bottom line&quot; number for each car; that is, they have an unspoken minimum price that they will accept for any car.</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":""},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>This paragraph includes two direct quotations and a paraphrase, all from Tara Browning&#39;s article.&nbsp; Each one is cited:<br />&nbsp;</p><ul style=\"padding-left:15px;\"><li>The first direct quotation is introduced by a signal phrase: <span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">Tara Browning (2016) notes in an article titled &quot;Rating the Reliability of Used Cars&quot;. . .</span> This signal phrase lets your readers know that the first part of the paragraph is your own and introduces the direct quotation.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />&nbsp;</li><li>The second direct quotation is also introduced by a signal phrase: <span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">As Browning notes. . .</span><br />&nbsp;</li><li>The paraphrase that begins <span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">In the old days. . .</span> is not introduced by a signal phrase, and it has a citation at the end that includes the author&#39;s last name and the date.<br />&nbsp;</li></ul><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\">Those who drove an AMC Gremlin or Pacer in the late 1970s would not have expected the massive improvements that the car industry would make in coming decades.&nbsp; Many older cars were difficult to work on, and for that reason repairs were expensive.&nbsp; The cars of the 1970s had many problems with power, performance, electrical systems&mdash;you name it.&nbsp; <span class=\"marker\">Tara Browning (2016)</span> notes in an article titled <span class=\"marker\">&quot;Rating the Reliability of Used Cars&quot; </span>that &quot;domestic cars and foreign cars were equally bad&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(p. 40).</span> Today&#39;s cars are designed to make it easy for mechanics to fix most problems, which are now diagnosed by hooking the car up to a&nbsp;computer.&nbsp; <span class=\"marker\">As Browning notes,</span> &quot;Cars today are not just four wheels and engine; they are sophisticated computers&quot; <span class=\"marker\"> (p. 40)</span>.&nbsp; In the old days, repairing a car required a lot of guesswork, but today, computers help mechanics pinpoint the exact problem quickly and accurately <span class=\"marker\">(Browning, 2016)</span>.&nbsp; </span></p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>If you are including information from different authors or sources, then the citation rules apply to each author or source.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Citing different sources within the same paragraph"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<p>This paragraph from your article about used cars includes information from three different sources.<br />&nbsp;</p><ul style=\"padding-left:15px;\"><li>Arthur Upton wrote a book published in 2017.&nbsp; He notes that certain car models are used as fleet cars because they hold their values better than other models.<br />&nbsp;</li><li>Gary Wilfred wrote an article titled &quot;Get the Car You Want for the Price You Want,&quot; which was published in the March 2004 issue of the <em>Journal of Sales Psychology</em>.&nbsp; This is a direct quotation from p. 42: &quot;By doing their research upfront, buyers will have more negotiating power on any car they might want to purchase.&quot;<br />&nbsp;</li><li>&nbsp;Marta&nbsp;Lisiewicz published a blog entry titled &quot;The Perils of Pre-Owned Cars&quot; in <em>The Car Blog</em> on May 14, 2017.&nbsp; In the sixth paragraph, she wrote, &quot;A fleet car is leased by a company for use by its employees, or it is used for business purposes, such as Uber or Lyft rides.&quot;</li></ul><p>Add the correct citations to the paragraph:</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p style=\"line-height:180%;\"><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">What exactly is a &quot;pre-owned&quot; car?&nbsp; You may assume that all used cars were owned by individuals, but often they were fleet cars.&nbsp; A fleet car is &quot;leased by a company for use by its employees, or it is used for business purposes, such as Uber or Lyft rides&quot;&nbsp;<jumc ju-mc=\"mc_ccc41d32-9d39-c07a-6d24-b5b312c130c1\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\"><strong>ID: mc_ccc4...</strong></jumc><span>.&nbsp; </span>Some fleet cars have been driven many miles (think about all the miles driven by an Uber driver), but some have very low mileage because the owner (perhaps a business executive) did not use the vehicle very often.&nbsp; </span><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;font-size:15px;\">Often, fleet car models hold their value better than other car models, because they tend to be very reliable. Integrating sources into your writing<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">&nbsp;,</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><ul><li>Use the words and ideas of others to support your own ideas.</li><li>Do not string together a series of direct&nbsp;quotations, paraphrases, and summaries without including your own ideas.</li><li>Try beginning with a statement that tells what you believe, and then insert a direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary of a source that confirms, proves, or explains your belief.</li><li>Explain the connection between your belief and the source material.</li></ul><p><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/picture_it.png\" style=\"width: 27px; height: 27px;\" /> <a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/JCS100/3/Tryit2_Pictureit_Structuringyourwriting.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=no,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=yes,dependent=yes,width=826,left=100,height=750,top=50'); return false;\">Structuring your writing: Picture it!</a>&nbsp; <a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/JCS100/3/Try_it_2_screen_reader_picture_it_structuring_your_writing.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/accessible_icon.png\" style=\"width: 17px; height: 20px;\" /><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">Screen reader version of Structuring your writing, opens in a new tab</span></a>&nbsp;</p></td></tr></tbody></table>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Putting it all together"},{"settings":{"showAudio":0,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"fullWhiteboard":0,"showRFB":0},"leftText":"<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-summary\" style=\"width:90%;\"><thead><tr><th scope=\"col\">Remember! Using signal phrases<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">&nbsp;,</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><ul><li>Use a signal phrase such as <em>According to Jones (2014)</em> to show where your ideas end and the words or ideas of another begin.</li><li>When you use a signal phrase for a direct quotation, include the page number in parentheses at the end of the quotation.</li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p><table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-summary\" style=\"width:90%;\"><thead><tr><th scope=\"col\">Remember! More than one citation in a paragraph<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">&nbsp;,</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><ul><li>When you paraphrase, summarize, or quote a source more than once within a paragraph, acknowledge the source each time you use it with either a signal phrase or a citation in parentheses.</li><li>When you use multiple signal phrases to acknowledge the same source within a paragraph, only include a citation in parentheses with the first signal phrase.&nbsp;This pattern starts over with each new paragraph.</li><li>When you use multiple sources within a paragraph, the same rules apply.&nbsp; Each time you use a piece of information from a source, you must acknowledge it.</li></ul><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/picture_it.png\" Note that you provide a page number because you are using a direct quotation."}},"rightFloatText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">From your article: </span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td>Unfortunately, while many people cherish dreams of owning a brand-new car, buying a new car might not be the best financial decision.&nbsp; On average, a new car loses 11% of its value as soon as you purchase it.&nbsp; For example, if you pay $25,000 for a car, then its worth immediately decreases to $22,250, even before you drive it one mile (Browning, 2016).&nbsp; That means that your brand new car loses a large chunk of its value as soon as it leaves the lot!&nbsp; However, there is good news for those on a budget and those who want to spend their money wisely.&nbsp; Often, the best solution is to buy a used, or &quot;pre-owned,&quot; car.</td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>"}
